comments.commentBody:
Rahm Emmanuel has chosen a unique idea in modern politics. Usually when a politician gets the job he sought from the voters he becomes like a man sitting in a chair who is in the crosshairs of a sniper, only the gun fires a bullet that can take years to hit its target. Typically the guy in the 'Hot Seat' then proceeds to do what he wants while making the "Hard Choices" in such a way as to make sure when those bullets finally hit, he's no longer in that seat, having ideally moved on to a more comfy, powerful, and higher paying one.

Bush & Cheney almost attained that perfect timing, but alas the Massive Economic Collapse of 2007 arrived just a tad sooner than they expected. Still the Republicans are doing an excellent job of hanging their mess around Rahm's previous bosses neck.

The new mayor is seemingly tackling the impossible, and only time will tell if he can do all he says. But one thing in America is new, the middle class has finally figured out that no matter who was in the seat, it was really they who were in the crosshairs all along. The true rahm-ifications from that new reality idoubt even Rahm can predict.

Having a professional sports team is a sign of a serious state and city.

To loose an NFL team is a nightmare, ask Cleveland. Pretty soon you miss them and you en up building a stupid stadium to get them back, they generate a lot of revenue for the state other other than just ticket sales.

Let's close every park, not repair any roads, not spend a penny until every darling child has their own personal state sponsored teacher, nurse and chef, maybe then we can move onto everything else.

Wrong, the economic impact from losing a team and what it will mean for the state long term would be far worse than shelling out some money for a stadium.

Build it, make it great, host a super bowl, make your money back.

Be as Scandanavian as you want but not with this.

"That’s why the issue for Chicago, and the nation, is the same: Can we cut enough fat to keep building enough muscle — while reforming taxes to raise more revenue — so we pay for the excesses of the last 20 years while financing the tools our kids and innovators need to thrive in the next 20?"

Let's hope that we don't follow the Chicago way of raising taxes to pay off the mayor's cronies.

You did not specify how you plan to "reform" taxes, but how about for starters we raise the capital gains tax, slap a hefty tax on Wall Street trades (especially the high speed computerized variety), make FICA taxes progressive above the current hundred-odd thousand cap, obviously allow the Bush tax cuts to expire, and go ahead with that five percent millionaire surtax. In other words, tax wealth the same way we tax work.

We should not believe the canard that repatriation of corporate profits will produce jobs. We tried that once, and thousands of jobs were actually lost. And no more "free" trade! It's too late probably to undo the last trifecta giveaway to multinationals, but at least we can vote out the scoundrels who gave them the big A-OK. That would be most Republicans and not a few quisling Democrats too.

And for heavens sake, get rid of the White House Council on Jobs and Competiveness and most especially its chairman, Jeff Immelt of G.E.! This multimillionaire expects the rest of us to cheer for his success, even as he offshores thousands of jobs, pays no corporate taxes, but still expects his welfare check from Uncle Sam in the form of tax credits to cover his fictional losses. The so-called jobs council is nothing but a super lobby roundtable, whispering their deregulation wish lists in the president's ear.

But back to Rahm -- did you happen to ask him exactly what went on behind closed doors when he gave away the public option to private insurers and nixed the resale of Canadian drugs so that Big Pharma could profit from the Affordable Care Act as much as the predatory insurers?

While it's great that Rahmbo's back in Chicago, his replacement is not exactly a man of the people either. By his own admission, Big Banker Bill Daley spends his days tuned in to CNBC to make sure his precious markets aren't panicking.

If it were not for Occupy Wall Street, Occupy USA, and Occupy the Whole World, I would be feeling mighty depressed right now.

Never should a column be written, a letter sent, or speech made concerning government spending without including the absolute necessity and common sense of slashing military spending. The cuts being considered and bemoaned now are petty compared to what ought to occur. Cutting military spending by 50% starting now would leave us stronger, not weaker. Do let let up the pressure on our politicians to do so.
Carl, Portland

What is to say? There is no money. That is money for schools, health and other human needs.

Where there is money available is for political donationa. Just look at the millions in the politicians warchests. Want to know where the money is? Just look in the ways that the moneyed corportations or Wall Street entities move their money to "elected" public officials.

This must be curtailed. This country should no longer be for sale so boldly.

Thank you for a thoughtful assessment of a progressive mayor we are proud of.
You might also put in a good word for our beleaguered governor, Pat Quinn. Mr. Quinn is still wildly and soundly reviled for doing what other, less honest politicians everywhere are avoiding: he raised our income tax in Illinois last year (not to mention outlawing the death penalty). I applaud two honest, far-seeing politicians of Illinois.

The education gap here is real and startling. The CEO of Siemens says that he has 3000 position in the U.S. that his global firm cannot fill because the applicants are not qualified. We are in trouble, real trouble and right now we are just hearing about the foothills. Wait til we find out about the Himalayas.

No idea what Friedman is talking about. Emanuel's  agenda consists really of one item: privatize more public services to open them up for private profit, leaving the consumers of those services, the service workers, and the tax payer to foot the bill. Union busting and selling off public utilities isn't "wise". It's more of what got us into this mess in the first time.

Rahm Emanuel said “I had two young C.E.O.’s in the health care software business in the other day, sitting at this table. I asked them: ‘What can I do to help you?’ They said, ‘We have 50 job openings today, and we can’t find people.’ ”

Well, there you have it: solid, incontrovertible proof that the only reason for joblessness in America today is that people lack the necessary skills. All they need to do is pursue the proper training in science, engineering, and other technical professions, and presto, the problem is solved.

Of course, Mr. Friedman's analysis overlooks a few inconvenient facts. Like the fact that once you have a degree in science or engineering, you are competing with equally well-trained people in countries with a much lower cost of living. And the fact that higher education is becoming increasingly unaffordable for the children of the middle and working classes. But acknowledging such problems would mean questioning the basic fairness of America's economic and political system. Much better, instead, to blame the victims.
How about voting out of office every politician who took Grover Norquists's pledge to never vote to raise taxes?
If you want to invest in the future, more, raise revenues, and change the mood, by taxing consumption, more.

This makes good sense.  What doesn't make sense is the continuing refusal to return the taxes the rich pay to the level they were before Bush put us in our ever deepening hole.  No new jobs appear. It has been raised to the level of a kind of religious doctrine:  Somewhere, if we hope and wait and suffer long enough, there is pie in the sky.

To increase revenue, how about actually enforcing the city's law against cell-phone use while driving? Given the constancy with which I am surrounded by flagrant violators, I suspect the fines collected would go a long way toward erasing the deficit.

I wish Rahm well.  But if he thinks that the Chicago school system is going to produce educated graduates with the teachers' union he is stuck with (unless he's got the guts to get rid of tenure) he will be waiting for a very long time.

This is exactly what the country needs. Little talk and more action. Rahm is not a great orator but he delivers. You may like it or not but there is no more time for politics.

It may sound ridiculous but he reminds me of Napoleon and other "short" leaders of the past (some of whom I'd better not mention) that effectively changed the course of history. As long as he stays on the People's side we'll be all right.

'Cut and invest'? The mayor of Atlanta has been doing that successfully since he was elected. The quality of life there has improved tremendously for families and single people. Meanwhile in Wisconsin, public employees are maligned and in Texas, low wage jobs are the norm.

When will we recognize that we are all in this together?
Occupy!

Now if only the Federal Government would do the same.

I'm sure there are a lot of empty suits and skirts there that could be let go. I'm also sure there are departments that need qualified people.

Simply extending the school day won't make a difference if the kids aren't prepared to learn.  This means that their families need to create an environment were homework can and will get done, where reading happens and where students can get a decent meal and a full night of sleep.  If this doesn't happen, the best teachers in the world won't be able to make a difference.

I love a pragmatic approach! I believe many of us - the unheard masses - are yearning for the type of people who will govern by forgetting politics and putting the welfare of our people and the future of our nation first. Let's hear it for Rahm Emanuael.

On antoher note - I was thinking the other day that our taxes need to reflect the cost of certain behaviors and products. Like taxing carbon, but using the money to insulate pulic buildings and providing first class public transportation. Or, taxing high fat/high sugar foods and using the money to provide preventive care medicine. Tax TV and video games and put the money into education. We need to start being smart as a nation and using our resources to futher the common good.

Sure, as long as we don't have to work with him, elect him to political office or live near him. That said, "senstive" men are just as bad, maybe worse for all their false advertising.
Hemingway was a gifted writer of the highest caliber. He spares the reader overwraught adjectives and fluff. He gets to the point. I wonder what he would do with today's blogs.

Fifty years ago, shortly after the death of Ernest Hemingway, I staged a "show" for Luther League at the University of Pittsburgh. Someone had backed out of an engagement for the evening, giving only one or two days notice. So, I wrote a brief article about walking the sun-drenched streets of Ketchum, Idaho, along the bleached walls of the shops on the main street, and up onto the porch of a house. When I entered the house, I found it dark and dank, and as I passed from one room to another, I found a cadaver on the floor -- the late Ernest Hemingway. The body is dead but the life endures.

When the night finally arrived, I had my fellow students arrange all the chairs to face a blank wall, then I placed myself behind them and from the other side of a curtain, I read that article, followed by three short stories, "Today is Friday," "A Clean, Well-Lighted Place," and "The End of Something."

Curiously, nobody complained about this bizarre presentation, which I felt was a fitting tribute to Hemingway's bizarre life.

Leo Toribio
Pittsburgh, PA

Oh gosh -- Maureen -- I wouldn't want to be Daisy Buchanan any more than I'd want to be Hadley Hemingway.

Daisy's a horrible person. She swills illegal alcohol during Prohibition, romances in secret a bootlegger who made his fortune trafficking what was then an illegal drug, while she's married to the kind of ultra-conservative borderline-fascist pit bull hypocrite who kept Alcohol Prohibition going for 13 years.

She drives when she's drunk, kills her husband's mistress, and then lets her bootlegger lover take the blame and be murdered because of it.

Then she sails off into the distance on a cloud of floaty white silk.

What a bone-chilling sociopath Fitzgerald gave us. It's such a great story because the romantic white silk heroine turns out to be so thoroughly rotten.

Read David Pogue's unrestrained, enthusiastic review of iCloud. Then read ArsTechnica's piece:
http://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2011/10/problems-upgrading-to-ios-5-te... Through his sycophantic "reviews," Pogue is doing a disservice not only to the NYT readers, but to the Times itself. Isn't it about time to re-evaluate his contribution to the newspaper?

Hemingway was a fraud, a drunk, and a fool, that was an entertaining but hardly gifted writer.  Read any credible biography and these facts will emerge.  In particular, his 'war hero' story, when he was injured candies as a volunteer ambulance driver - in Italy - is particularly telling.  He wrote some very entertaining books, but please do not lionize this charlatain!
